name: Betterman v. Montana
question: Is it a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial to postpone sentencing for fourteen months after a guilty plea has been issued?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Sixth Amendment’s guarantee of a speedy trial does not extend past a guilty verdict or guilty plea.

name: Heffernan v. City of Paterson
question: Does the First Amendment prohibit the government from demoting a public employee based on a supervisor’s perception that the employee supports a political candidate?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a government employee who is demoted because of perceived involvement in protected political activity is entitled to challenge his demotion under the First Amendment, even if the demotion was based on a factual mistake.

name: Montanile v. Board of Trustees of the National Elevator Industrial Health Benefit Plan
question: For purposes of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, is a reimbursement to an employee welfare benefit plan “appropriate equitable relief” if the identified source of the reimbursement has already been spent or disbursed?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 does not allow for a suit to recover reimbursement of an asset that has been fully disbursed on non-traceable items such as services.

name: Commil USA, LLC v. Cisco Systems, Inc.
question: Is a good-faith belief that a patent is invalid a defense to a claim of induced infringement?
description: A case in which the Court decided that a good-faith belief that a patent is invalid is not a defense to a claim of induced infringement.

name: Rodriguez v. United States
question: Is the use of a K-9 unit, after the conclusion of a traffic stop and without reasonable suspicion of criminal activity, a violation of the Fourth Amendment prohibition on unreasonable search and seizures?
description: A case in which the Court held that the use of a K-9 unit at the conclusion of an otherwise lawful traffic stop constituted an unreasonable search and seizure in violation of the Fourth Amendment.

name: Teva Pharmaceuticals USA, Inc. v. Sandoz, Inc.
question: Can a district court's finding of fact in the construction of a patent claim be reviewed de novo, as though for the first time, which the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit requires and did in this case?
description: A case in which the Court ruled that a federal appellate court can only overturn a district court’s finding of fact if those findings were determined to be “clearly erroneous.”

name: BG Group PLC v. Argentina
question: Is it the role of a court to decide whether a precondition to arbitration has been satisfied?
description: A case in which the Court held that it is the duty of the arbitrating party in a contract lawsuit to interpret provisions outlined in the contract.

name: Heimeshoff v. Hartford Life & Accident Insurance Co.
question: When should the statute of limitations period for judicial review of an ERISA disability benefit decision begin?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Employment Retirement Income Security Act does not mandate a statute of limitations, allowing both parties in an insurance suit to mutually agree on a timeframe in which civil suits may be brought to court.

name: Heimeshoff v. Hartford Life & Accident Insurance Co.
question: When should the statute of limitations period for judicial review of an ERISA disability benefit decision begin?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Employment Retirement Income Security Act does not mandate a statute of limitations, allowing both parties in an insurance suit to mutually agree on a timeframe in which civil suits may be brought to court.

name: Limelight Networks v. Akamai Technologies
question: Did the Federal Circuit court err in holding that a defendant may be liable for inducing patent infringement under § 271(b) even if no party committed direct infringement under §271(a)?
description: A case in which the Court held that a party is not liable for patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271(b) unless the party has also violated Section 217(a)o or any other statutory provision.

name: Already LLC v. Nike
question: Did Already's counterclaim create a justiciable controversy sufficient to allow the District Court to exercise subject matter jurisdiction?
description: A case in which the Court held that a covenant not to sue invalidates a company’s counterclaim for trademark enforcement.

name: Salinas v. Texas
question: Does the Fifth Amendment's Self-Incrimination Clause protects a defendant's refusal to answer questions asked by law enforcement before he has been arrested or read his Miranda rights?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Fifth Amendment's Self-Incrimination clause does not protect individuals that have not been arrested.

name: Wos v. E.M.A. et al.
question: Does federal Medicaid law prohibit North Carolina's third-party liability statutes from mandating reimbursement of medical expenses from a patient's lump-sum settlement?
description: A case in which the Court held that federal law preempts North Carolina's state law regarding reimbursement of medical expenses from a patient's settlement.

name: Howes v. Fields
question: Does federal law automatically require Miranda warnings before questioning jail or prison inmates about issues unrelated to the cases for which they were incarcerated?
description: A case in which the Court held that a prisoner, currently held in jail, did not have his Miranda rights violated when he was questioned inside the jail for a different crime.

name: Howes v. Fields
question: Does federal law automatically require Miranda warnings before questioning jail or prison inmates about issues unrelated to the cases for which they were incarcerated?
description: A case in which the Court held that a prisoner, currently held in jail, did not have his Miranda rights violated when he was questioned inside the jail for a different crime.

name: Kappos v. Hyatt
question:
(1) Can a plaintiff, who is appealing the denial of an application of a patent by commencing a civil action against the Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) in a federal district court pursuant to 35 U.S.C. § 145, introduce new evidence that could have been presented to the agency in the first instance?

(2) When new evidence is introduced under Section 145, can the district court decide de novo the factual questions to which the evidence pertains, without giving deference to the prior decision of the PTO?
description: A case in which the Court held that a patent applicant's ability to introduce new evidence in a civil action against the Patent and Trademark Office was only limited by the Federal Rules of Evidence and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

name: Kappos v. Hyatt
question:
(1) Can a plaintiff, who is appealing the denial of an application of a patent by commencing a civil action against the Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) in a federal district court pursuant to 35 U.S.C. § 145, introduce new evidence that could have been presented to the agency in the first instance?

(2) When new evidence is introduced under Section 145, can the district court decide de novo the factual questions to which the evidence pertains, without giving deference to the prior decision of the PTO?
description: A case in which the Court held that a patent applicant's ability to introduce new evidence in a civil action against the Patent and Trademark Office was only limited by the Federal Rules of Evidence and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

name: Astra USA v. Santa Clara County
question: Can health care providers sue drug makers for overcharging public hospitals for prescription drugs?
description: A case in which the Court held that health care providers cannot sue drug makers for overcharging public hospitals for prescription drugs.

name: Astra USA v. Santa Clara County
question: Can health care providers sue drug makers for overcharging public hospitals for prescription drugs?
description: A case in which the Court held that health care providers cannot sue drug makers for overcharging public hospitals for prescription drugs.

name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
question: Does the Eleventh Amendment categorically preclude an independent state agency from bringing an action in federal court against state officials for prospective injunctive relief to remedy a violation of federal law under the doctrine of Ex Parte Young?
description: A case in which the Court held that a federal court may hear a lawsuit for prospective injunctive relief against state officials brought by another agency of the same state.

name: Abbott v. Abbott
question: Does a clause that prohibits one parent from removing a child from a country without the other parent's consent confer a "right of custody" within the meaning of the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Hague Convention gave a father a right to have his child brought back to Chile from Texas after the child's mother violated her divorce agreement that required both parents' consent for the child to be taken out of Chile.

name: Reed Elsevier v. Muchnick
question: Does Section 411(a) of the Copyright Act restrict subject matter jurisdiction of federal courts over copyright infringement actions?
description: A case in which the Court held that the registration requirement of Section 411(a) of the Copyright Act is a precondition to filing a copyright infringement claim.
